subject: Re: Not another one-- for crying out loud!!
author: billliscomb
full_text:
Just dug out the manual for the Icom R-75 shortwave receiver that has 
been in box for 2 years since I moved.  It has programable scan start 
and stop frequencies, and variable scan steps and speed, along with 
various modes - USB/LSB/RTTY/CW/AM/FM - AND programable wide and 
narrow filters.  All of these settings, along with AGC, ANL and other 
functions can be changed while the radio is scanning.  Not very 
portable and rather expensive, but it is here.  I've got 2 projects 
ahead of starting to fool around with this, but I imagine it could be 
useful in finding frequencies/modes that work.  Ideas?
Willy  






--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Frank Sumption <franks-boxes@...> 
wrote:
>
> 
>  I have 49, and 31 meter shortwave bands, plus AM. The shortwave 
tuning might be tricky cuz the band width is less than half the size 
of the AM band, about 500 khz, so instead of tuning over a megahertz 
with 8 volts, you're tuning about half that with the same tuning 
voltage. So far I only have the local oscillators working, still need 
the input RF amp for each band. The two cans close to the chip are IF 
transformers, the three on the bottom edge o fthe board is the local 
oscillator tank circuits.  On the highest band I'm using a red LED 
for a varactor, it has almost the perfect capacitance value. 31m on 
my Sony is 9400 khz to 9800 khz, and 49m is 5900 to 6200khz.  Still, 
how well it works, if at all, is yet to be seen.
>  
>  
>  I really-really need a life!
